title: Newtons third law-tension along an ideal string

content.question: Two boxes of unequal mass are pulled upward at a constant speed by String <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, as shown. Box <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Box <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are connected by String <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Both String <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and String <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are ideal strings. Which of the following correctly describes the tension in String <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> at Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> ?

choices.label: The tension at Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is greater.
The tension at Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> is greater.
The tensions at Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> are equal.
The tensions cannot be compared without knowing the relative masses of the boxes.

content.answer: The tensions at Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> are equal.
